title: 103_hr2328
content: The Act may be cited as the "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993". Congressional findings and purpose are outlined. The Congress finds that conserving natural and cultural resources through a Public Lands Corps can benefit young men and women by providing education and work opportunities, while also benefiting the economy and environment. Many public lands and Indian reservations require labor-intensive rehabilitation and restoration work that federal agencies cannot carry out alone. Youth conservation corps have a good record of maintaining these facilities. The purpose of this Act is to perform cost-effective conservation work on public and Indian lands, expose young individuals to public service, expand educational opportunities, and assist government agencies in research and education tasks related to natural and cultural resources. Youth conservation corps have a good track record of restoring and maintaining facilities in partnership with government agencies. The Act aims to expand educational opportunities by rewarding national service participants with increased access to higher education or job training. It also seeks to stimulate interest in conservation careers among young individuals by exposing them to professionals in land managing agencies. The Act aims to expand educational opportunities by rewarding national service participants with increased access to higher education or job training. It also seeks to stimulate interest in conservation careers among young individuals by exposing them to professionals in land managing agencies. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Corps" as the Public Lands Corps, "public lands" as lands owned or administered by the United States, "qualified youth or conservation corps" as programs offering work for individuals aged 16-25 in natural or cultural settings, and "Indian tribe" as any recognized tribe or band. The term "Indian tribe" refers to any recognized Indian tribe, band, nation, or group by the Secretary of the Interior, including Native village corporations and groups established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The term "Indian" pertains to a member of an Indian tribe, while "Indian lands" encompass real property owned or held in trust by Indian tribes with restrictions on alienation. The term "State" includes various regions within the United States and its territories. The term "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" refers to projects involving the preservation of natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources in Rico, Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The Public Lands Corps Program is established. Establishment of Public Lands Corps in the Department of the Interior and Agriculture for young men and women aged 16-25. Enrollees must be U.S. citizens or residents, have a high school diploma or equivalent, and not have dropped out of school. Enrollees are exempt from civil service laws. Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for projects. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can utilize the Public Lands Corps or qualified youth/conservation corps for conservation projects on public or Indian lands. Preference is given to projects with long-term public benefits, instilling work ethic, being labor-intensive, prompt initiation, and providing educational opportunities. All projects must be consistent with the provisions of the Act. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can provide necessary services and facilities for conservation projects on public or Indian lands. They are authorized to establish conservation centers for program purposes and may arrange logistical support from military installations. All projects must be consistent with relevant laws and management plans. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can establish conservation centers with basic health and safety standards enforced. They may also collaborate with state and local agencies for management. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. The Resource Assistant Program allows the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to place qualified college students or recent graduates in Federal land managing agencies for research or technical functions. Participants are recruited from colleges nationwide with a focus on diversity. The program aims to increase workforce diversity and provide opportunities for college students and graduates. The Resource Assistant Program aims to increase workforce diversity by placing college students or recent graduates in Federal land managing agencies. Existing nonprofit organizations can also implement the program, with private funding required from participating organizations. Annual reports evaluating the program are mandatory. The Resource Assistant Program requires agencies to submit an annual report assessing the program's impact, including the value of work contributed by Resource Assistants to the agency's mission. SEC. 6. Living allowances and terms of service for participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program are provided by the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture. Living allowances should not exceed those in the national service program. Participants agree to a term of service set by the Secretaries. SEC. 7. Educational benefits or awards are provided for participants. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program are eligible for national service awards and forbearance on Stafford Loans. The benefits and awards eligibility criteria are determined by the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture, and loan forbearance is granted upon request. During service as a participant or Resource Assistant, borrowers are eligible for post-service educational benefits or awards under specific regulations. SEC. 8. NONDISPLACEMENT. The nondisplacement requirements of the National and Community Service Act of 1990 apply to activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps. SEC. 9. FUNDING. Cost sharing for projects on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps is authorized up to 75% by the Secretary of the Interior and Secretary of Agriculture, with the remaining 25% to be provided by nonfederal sources. No cost sharing is required for projects on Indian lands. The Public Lands Corps may receive contributions from a foundation associated with a Federal land managing agency. Funding for programs under this section is available under the National and Community Service Act. Under this section, the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can receive funds for programs, including the Resource Assistant Program, under the National and Community Service Act of 1990. Funds will be provided without restrictions, and there are authorized appropriations for carrying out this Act.
